text: for the rkde() function in R, what is "n" supposed to take on, the documentation says number of observations -- does this mean the number of observations in our input data or the number of forecasted observations?
That is the number of observations you want to be sampled from the distribution!
so in Dr. LaBarr's notes, what was the reasoning for choosing n=1000?
You can make that number anything you want <@U1LMHQY9E>.  1000 gives a good practice example for us to view
so it's essentially the size of the sample we are going to use for our built distribution... that's how it's making sense to me but good chance i'm wrong
That sounds right to me.  I'll look at my notes later to make it official

<@U1LMHQY9E> I have it in my notes that it's a somewhat arbitrary decision how big of a sample size you want to use.  Obviously you're weighing the time it takes to calculate that many simulations vs the additional accuracy of the model.  The rule of thumb Dr LaBarr gave in class is you need to quadruple your number of simulations to double your accuracy.
<@U1LMHQY9E>: I increased that number until I stopped seeing the distribution change (changing to my eye anyway). Just my philosophy on it.
interesting... i may go with that, did you set a specific bucket size?
<@U1LMHQY9E>: I'll have to check. I don't remember...
